results.title: Tauondi Aboriginal Community College
results.description_rich: Whether you are lookin for Aboriginal Cultural Instructors for your school or organisation, or an Aboriginal Cultural Tour Guide during the holidays, Tauondi College can assist you.

results.title: Piltawodli Memorial
results.description_rich:
The Piltawodli Memorial was installed in May 2000 to commemorate National Sorry Day.

Piltawodli is a Kaurna word meaning 'possum place' arising from his name 'pilta' (possum) and 'wodli' (house or home). This park was so named because of the abundance of possums that lived in the once numerous River Red gum trees. Piltawodli was also the name given to a 'native location' established on the riverbanks in 1837

results.title: Doris Graham Commemorative Plaque
results.description_rich: Situated in Elder Park, the Doris Graham Commemorative Plaque is located adjacent to a River Red gum planted by the late Mrs Doris Graham. A significant Kaurna Elder, Mrs Graham held the mantle of the oldest woman in Adelaide for many years and was a signatory to Council's 1997 Rconciliation Vision Statement.

results.title: Adelaide Festival Centre Mural
results.description_rich:
Located at the Adelaide Festival Centre, Trevor Nickolls' untitled mural painting uses Aboriginal art techniques of cross hatching and dot painting, blended with a contemporary western technique.

The work deals with ideas of harmony and reconciliation between white Australian and Australian Aboriginal culture, between mind and body, and between man and nature.

results.title: Alice Dixon Tree
results.description_rich:
In 1992, a tree was planted in Victoria Square/Tarntanyangga to honour the memory of Alice Dixon, a Kaurna woman known throughout Australia and internationally for her untiring struggle to expose and stop the deaths of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in custody.

The original tree was damaged and a replacement tree was planted at the National Sorry Day event held in the Square on 26 May 2001. The replacement tree was required to be removed in March 2013 to undertake construction works to upgrade Victoria Square / Tarntanyangga. A new tree honouring Alice Dixon, together with lighting and a plaque, is planned to be installed on National Sorry Day on 26 May 2014.

results.title: The Aboriginal Flag
results.description_rich: The Aboriginal flag, designed by Harold Thomas, a Luritji man, was first flown in Victoria Square / Tarntanyangga in July 1971 at a land rights rally. Today, the Aboriginal flag has come to be a powerful symbol for reconciliation and hope for many Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

results.title: Victoria Square / Tarntanyangga
results.description_rich:
Victoria Square / Tarntanyangga features the permanently flown Aboriginal and Australian flags along with audio interpretive information about each of the flags.

The name Tarntanyangga means 'a place of the Red Kangaroo' and derives from tarnda 'red kangaroo', kanya 'rock' and ngga 'a location ending in, at, on' frequently found in Kaurna place names. 

Victoria Square / Tarntanyangga is still an important meeting place for Aboriginal people from all over the State. It is the location of many political and community-based Aboriginal events such as National Sorry Day and is the starting point for the annual National Aboriginal and Islander Day of Celebrations (NAIDOC) march.

results.title: Kaurna meyunna, Kaurna yarta tampendi
results.description_rich: This reconciliation sculptural work (commissioned by the Graham F Smith Peace Trust) is located at the forecourt to the Adelaide Festival Centre and offers an insight into Kaurna culture. It was dedicated to the Kaurna meyunna (people) in September 2002.

results.title: Adelaide Festival Centre Foundation Aboriginal Art Collection
results.description_rich: The vision for the Adelaide Festival Centre Foundation Aboriginal Art Collection is to create a unique collection of contemporary Australian Aboriginal art, post 1970 (since the construction of the Adelaide Festival Centre), which acknowledges, celebrates and honours South Australian and national Australian Aboriginal cultures, stories and people. The City of Adelaide provided funding over a five-year period to enable the Adelaide Festival Centre Trust to build a substantial Aboriginal art collection.
